info.game_comments:
(Jimmy: Hi, I'm Jimmy.)
(Sarah: And I'm Sarah of the Clue Crew at the New Orleans School of Cooking.)
(Jimmy: Today, we learn the difference between blackened...)
(Sarah: ...and burned.)

(2, 1).clue: This 3-word query might have been Mel Blanc's first words

(3, 1).clue: (Sarah's stirring up the clue.) Who wants dessert? I'm just whipping up the whiskey sauce to serve with this treat that's made with raisins, cinnamon, vanilla & stale baguettes

(4, 1).clue: The play was performed in 1597 during the Christmas festivities at this queen's court

(5, 1).clue: During the Soviet Era, cars were rare in Latvia so teens got licenses for these

(6, 1).clue: The 2 3-word phrases parents dread on Christmas are "Some assembly required" & these "not included"

(2, 2).clue: Blanc joined Hanna-Barbera to voice this character, Fred's neighbor & Betty's husband

(3, 2).clue: For brunch, whether you serve eggs Sardou or eggs St. Charles you'll top them off with this creamy sauce

(4, 2).clue: Costard says, "Remuneration! O, that's" this language's "word for three farthings"

(5, 2).clue: The fun-loving Latvians celebrate All-Fool's Day twice during this month, on the 1st & the 30th

(2, 3).clue: It was Mel Blanc's catchphrase when voicing a crested bird of the southwest U.S.

(3, 3).clue: (Jimmy's stirring up the pot, and the clue!) I'm sauteing sausage & chicken, & soon I'll add onions, celery, peppers & spices for this dish, whose name may come from the French word for ham

(4, 3).clue: Alicia Silverstone played the princess in this director's 2000 version of "Love's Labour's Lost"

(5, 3).clue: An Easter activity is building a swing, from a belief that swinging will repel these insects in summer

(6, 3).clue: When you get your "just desserts" these "come home to roost"

(2, 4).clue: For "Who Framed Roger Rabbit", Blanc revived 5 characters including Tweety & this other bird

(3, 4).clue: Monday is the traditional day for serving this "colorful" dish of legumes & grains

(4, 4).clue: Shakespeare used the name Rosaline twice; in "Love's Labour's Lost", & as the unseen first love of this man

(5, 4).clue: At the Summer Olympics in this year, the first the Latvians competed in after the USSR split up, they won 3 medals

(6, 4).clue: According to this man's lay, "If anything can go wrong, it will"

(2, 5).clue: As a railroad announcer on Jack Benny's radio & TV shows, Blanc called out the stations "Anaheim, Azusa and" this

(3, 5).clue: (Sarah gives the clue.) Today we're making this famous Creole confection that's chock full of pecans & brown sugar

(4, 5).clue: Some say "The Taming of the Shrew" may also have been called this, making it a prequel to "Love's Labour's Lost"

(5, 5).clue: This member of the Riga ballet moved on to the Kirov in 1967, then defected to the West in 1974

(6, 5).clue: In "One man's loss is another man's gain" you can substitute "meat & "poison" or "trash" & this

(1, 1).clue: In May 1864, astride Traveller, he had to be stopped by a subordinate from riding into enemy fire

(2, 1).clue: Her nationally syndicated talk show began in St. Louis in 1983

(3, 1).clue: The son of slaves, he developed 118 products from sweet potatoes

(4, 1).clue: It's held against the neck before it's put

(5, 1).clue: Only the old church tower built in 1640 still stands in this, the first permanent English settlement in America

(6, 1).clue: In the '60s little girls pulled this "Chatty" doll's string & she said, "I love you"

(1, 2).clue: The USS Cairo was the first iron warship; it was completed before this Merrimack opponent

(2, 2).clue: On TV, she played the Meathead's main squeeze

(3, 2).clue: As a teenager, he had a successful business making nails, & later, hatpins; the cotton gin came later

(4, 2).clue: This object that's thrown isn't a carpenter's tool, but a metal ball attached to a wire & handle

(5, 2).clue: When traveling west, add one day to your calendar if you cross this (even if it takes only a minute)

(6, 2).clue: Mind your paws on this structure seen here

(1, 3).clue: David Dixon Porter served under this David, his foster brother, at the capture of New Orleans

(3, 3).clue: After moving to Santa Rosa, California, he developed new & improved varieties of plums & roses

(4, 3).clue: This women's competition includes 4 field events (plus 3 track)

(5, 3).clue: Buck Island Reef in this U.S. territory is one of the finest marine gardens in the Caribbean

(6, 3).clue: A Mozart aria is this kind of list of Don Giovanni's conquests

(1, 4).clue: This Secretary of the Treasury was on hand for the surrender of Norfolk

(2, 4).clue: Notorious WWII nickname of American-born Mildred Elizabeth Gillars

(4, 4).clue: In this event, though athletes clear a nearly 20-foot bar, they don't jump but use their running momentum

(5, 4).clue: The 8-story tower in this Italian city's Campo Dei Miracoli contains a 294-step staircase

(6, 4).clue: Similar to "catastrophe", this world comes from the Greek for "flood"

(1, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew gives the choo-choo clue.) On April 12, 1862, Union soldiers went on a rampage after stealing this Confederate locomotive

(2, 5).clue: Thomas Jefferson was president when the first article was published about his affair with this woman

(3, 5).clue: After his death, his company became part of International Harvester Company

(4, 5).clue: Javier Sotomayor of this country retired in 2001 as the world record holder in the high jump

(5, 5).clue: The Luxembourg Palace is not in Luxembourg but in this country, where it serves as the meeting place of the senate

(6, 5).clue: Inflammation of membranes in the nose & throat

(0, 0).clue: In 1898 the word "telephone" made its debut in the Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary, as did this related word
